questions.instruction:
Questions 27–33
Reading Passage 3 has seven paragraphs, A–G.
Choose the correct heading for each paragraph from the list of headings below.
List of Headings i Moving rapidly across the desert ii Recreating the process in a laboratory iii Strange music created by human movement iv A potential threat to industry and communications v Dunes coming together and re-forming vi Needing a specific combination of conditions vii A continuous cycle viii The commonest type of dune ix Old superstitions demystified

options.label: i
options.text: Moving rapidly across the desert

options.label: ii
options.text: Recreating the process in a laboratory

options.label: iii
options.text: Strange music created by human movement

options.label: iv
options.text: A potential threat to industry and communications

options.label: v
options.text: Dunes coming together and re-forming

options.label: vi
options.text: Needing a specific combination of conditions

options.label: vii
options.text: A continuous cycle

options.label: viii
options.text: The commonest type of dune

options.label: ix
options.text: Old superstitions demystified

questions.instruction:
Questions 34–36
Choose the correct letter, A, B, C or D.

content.questionText: What are we told about linear dunes?

options.label: A
options.text: They are formed by strong winds blowing from one direction.

options.label: B
options.text: They can move up to 100 metres in a twelve-month period.

options.label: C
options.text: They develop in a recognisable shape.

options.label: D
options.text: They make up about 20% of the world's deserts.

questions.instruction:
Questions 34–36
Choose the correct letter, A, B, C or D.

content.questionText: Bagnold discovered that movement in barchans was caused by

options.label: A
options.text: the long straight shape of the dunes.

options.label: B
options.text: the particular composition of the dunes.

options.label: C
options.text: the exceptionally heavy nature of the sand grains.

options.label: D
options.text: the unusual strength of the wind in certain seasons.

questions.instruction:
Questions 34–36
Choose the correct letter, A, B, C or D.

content.questionText: Why does Dr Douady compare a barchan dune to a living organism?

options.label: A
options.text: It starts small and then increases in size.

options.label: B
options.text: It has an effect on its immediate surroundings.

options.label: C
options.text: Its relations with desert organisms are quite developed.

options.label: D
options.text: Its outline stays the same even after a period of movement.

questions.instruction:
Questions 37–40
Complete the summary below.
Choose ONE WORD ONLY from the passage for each answer.
Singing dunes Singing dunes, which belong to the type of dunes known as 37 , produce a very loud sound which is transmitted at a low frequency. Researchers have worked out that sand grains fall down the dune and start vibrating against other grains, forming a sound wave. Research proves that the individual grains have a similar 38 , but the differences in dimensions alter the 39 of the 'song'. Each grain is covered with a mixture of different 40 , and this is vital to the sound production.

content.sentence: Singing dunes, which belong to the type of dunes known as _____ , produce a very loud sound which is transmitted at a low frequency. Researchers have worked out that sand grains fall down the dune and start vibrating against other grains, forming a sound wave.
